title: 114_hr2978
content: The Act may be cited as the "Thirteenth Amendment Commemorative Coin Act". The economic contributions of enslaved African-Americans to the American economy between 1691 and 1860 were immeasurable, building the foundations of America. Colonial economies in the Americas relied on enslaved African labor for survival, including the North American mercantile and shipping sectors. Enslaved Africans were also crucial in the political and economic capital of the United States. During the Civil War, President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, declaring all slaves in rebellious states free from January 1, 1863. This action added a new dimension to the war aims, shifting from preserving the Union to emancipation. The Civil War evolved from a conflict to preserve the Union to a crusade to end Black slavery and uphold the ideals of the Declaration of Independence. In 1864, the 13th Amendment was introduced in the Senate, prohibiting slavery and granting Congress the power to enforce it, passing with a vote of 38-6. Abolitionists and supporters of slavery debated the moral implications of slavery. President Lincoln played a key role in promoting the 13th Amendment to abolish slavery, ensuring it was included in the Republican Party's 1864 election platform. Various interpretations of natural law and the contradiction between slavery and inalienable rights were debated within the Republican Party. Representative John Farnsworth highlighted the belief of the Constitution's framers that slavery was against human rights. Charles Sumner sought a constitutional interpretation rejecting slavery as incompatible with moral law. Illinois was the first state to ratify the 13th Amendment in 1865, followed by 17 other states. Georgia became the 27th state to approve the Amendment in December 1865, meeting the constitutional requirement. The 13th Amendment was declared part of the Constitution by Secretary of State William Seward on December 18. The Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture was established by an Act of Congress in 2003. The NMAAHC receives surcharges from coin sales to fund its endowment and educational outreach, as it focuses on documenting African-American life including slavery and Reconstruction. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue commemorative coins for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment, including $50 bi-metallic platinum and gold coins, $20 gold coins, and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and gold/silver content. The coins minted under this Act for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment will have a diameter of 40.6 millimeters and contain .999 fine silver. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment will have a diameter of 40.6 millimeters and contain .999 fine silver, being legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will symbolize the Thirteenth Amendment and the end of slavery in America. They will feature inscriptions of the value, year "1865-2015", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will highlight the economic contributions of slavery and the journey from slavery to freedom. The $20 coins may have high relief elements, while the $50 coins could include an illustration of Columbia. The coins minted under this Act will symbolize the Thirteenth Amendment and the end of slavery in America. The design will feature an illustration of Columbia or a similar figure representing Liberty on the obverse, and a single eagle with stars on the reverse. The selection of the design will be done by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins is authorized under this Act. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1 of the issuance year. The Secretary may start sales of the coins before this date. The term "issuance year" is defined as the first calendar year with less than 2 commemorative coin programs authorized. Sesquicentennial dates will be the only dates for these coins, overriding section 5112(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code. Coins minted under this Act will not have an inscription of the year of minting or issuance. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. The sales of coins under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin, with all surcharges going to the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture. The museum will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge can exceed the specified amount. No surcharge can be included for issuing any coin under this Act if it would exceed the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs as per section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance for this limitation. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure minting coins incurs no net cost to the US Government and funds are not disbursed until all costs are recovered. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, as determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives.
